choices.D: A sheepdip computer defers a denial of service attack
choices.B: A sheepdip computer is another name for a honeypot
choices.C: A sheepdip computer is used only for virus-checking.

questions.question_text: Item 2If you come across a sheepdip machine at your client site, what would you infer?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Correct answer: C. A sheepdip computer is used only for virus-checking.
by Default a new log file is created everyday
log is created with the date as part of the log file name, so it is everyday

D. A new log is created each time the web server is started

This option is often implemented to track activities and events during the runtime of the web server, allowing for separate logs for different sessions or instances of the server.
Yes, new log file every day -- agreed this is wrong

Selected Answer: B
When IIS records the logs in the W3C Extended Log Format, the IIS stores all the logged events in the GMT format, instead of the format of the local time zone for the system. This point must be considered during the examination of the logs because IIS creates a new log file for the next day at midnight in GMT. Computer Hacking Forensics Investigator (CHFI) Version 10 EC-Council Pg. 928

Selected Answer: B
by Default a new log file is created everyday

Selected Answer: B
shuold be B

Selected Answer: B
I just read the CHFI documentation regarding IIS logging. Module 9, page 928 "IIS stores all the logged events in the GMT format (...) This point must be considered during the examination of the logs becasue IIS creates a new log file for the next day at midnight GMT"

Definetely B

Selected Answer: B
by Default a new log file is created everyday

questions.question_text: When examining the log files from a Windows IIS Web Server, how often is a new log file created?

choices.D: a new log is created each time the Web Server is started
choices.C: a new log file is created each week
choices.B: a new log file is created everyday
choices.A: the same log is used at all times

discussion.content:
Answer is D.

If it's wireless the "hacker" can flush the data out of the card, that is why it needs to be in the bag

Def should be a PDA. You would keep a phone inside of a StrongHold bag. Wireless card is going to be in the same class as a data storage device. Why would a wireless card be singled out? Makes no sense compared to an electronic communications device
How could a Wireless card communicate on its own without a power source other than an NFC capable one? I've never heard of a NFC capable Wireless Card.
I believe the option A should be PDA, that is typo for PDAPDA?
Upon a second thought, there is no option for PDA. Therefore, the answer cannot be A which is PDAPDA.

A should be the answer. As without connecting, an wireless card is unusable. But in case of PDA, it is best practice to keep it turned on and hence should be put inside strongholds to deprive any communication.

questions.question_text: What type of equipment would a forensics investigator store in a StrongHold bag?
Which part of the Windows Registry contains the user's password file?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Windows user passwords are stored in the Security Accounts Manager (SAM). The SAM database is under HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE registry entry

questions.question_text: What feature of Decryption Collection allows an investigator to crack a password as quickly as possible?

choices.B: Distribute processing over 16 or fewer computers
